start.text: Cambyses II, King of the Persians, has just dispatched a herald to Egypt with a peculiar message for Amasis, King of the Egyptians. Cambyses has requested the hand of Amasis' daughter in marriage. Amasis finds himself in quite a bind.  Amasis is sorely afraid of the power of Persia. At the same time, he knows full well that Cambyses would make her not his queen but his mistress. As such he finds he can neither give his daughter nor deny her.

next_a.text: Amasis finds himself in quite a bind. Amasis is sorely afraid of the power of Persia. At the same time, he knows full well that Cambyses would make his daughter not his queen but his mistress. As such he finds he can neither give his daughter nor deny her.

choices.text: Submit to the request and send his daughter off to Persia to be married to Cambyses
Find a stand-in to disguise as his daughter and attempt to fool Cambyses
Have the herald killed and his head returned to Cambyses

submission_choice.text: You opted for the path of appeasement in search of an easy way out. You chose to compromise on your morales in the vain hope that you might preserve you status. In the end, you lose both. Cambyses proceeds with his invasion, the kingdom collapses, and Amasis is granted no reprieve. And what became of his daughter? That much we will never know.

optimal_choice.text: Reasoning that he could neither send his daughter nor refuse Cambyses, Amasis bethought himself of a very tall and fair damsel called Nitetis, daughter of the former king Apries, and all that was left of that family. He decked her out with raiment and golden ornaments and sent her to the Persians as if she were his own daughter.

bold_choice.text: You made a bold move, and an uncompromising move at that. You upheld your morale fortitude and defended your daughter's honor. Unfortunately, it was also one of the last decisions Amasis would make. When Cambyses received the remains of his herald he was furious and marched directly on Egypt. When Amasis was finally delivered to the Persian King, he was treated so harshly as to defy description.

next_c.text: After a while, the king greeting her as the daughter of Amasis, the damsel said, 'King, you know not how Amasis has decieved you: he decked me out with ornaments and sent me to you to pass for his own daughter; but I am in truth the daughter of his master Apries, whom he and other Egyptians rebelled against and slew.

invade_egypt.text: It was these words and this reason which sparked in Cambyses such great anger as to compel him to invade Egypt.
